title: Arthur Andersen Typeface
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317183230im_/http:/typophile.com/files/AA_5227.jpg)

Hello – I am trying to identify the type that Arthur Andersen’s original type signature was set in.

Thanks!

Font: 

 Custom Type 

Solved By: 

 [kthomps5](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317183230/http:/typophile.com/user/175823 "View user profile.")
author: mustachioed

comments.content:
Very similar to Palatino, but with smaller serifs and a few refinements:

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/palatino/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317183230/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/palatino/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/palatino/")

Yeah, Palatino was my first thought until I started to compare them side-by-side.

Thanks for the reply, kthomps5.

Could have been a custom job by Joe Finocchiaro:  
 [http://luc.devroye.org/fonts-39089.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317183230/http:/luc.devroye.org/fonts-39089.html "http://luc.devroye.org/fonts-39089.html")

But I think Alan Fletcher is a better bet:  
 [http://www.alanfletcherarchive.com/archive/corporate-identity](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317183230/http:/www.alanfletcherarchive.com/archive/corporate-identity "http://www.alanfletcherarchive.com/archive/corporate-identity")

I also cycled through dozens of Palatino-like faces, and found no good match, so I'm betting it is custom.

I believe the Finocchiaro is the updated riff on Bankers Gothic:  
 [http://www.joefino.com/Logo\_html/L35\_Arthur%20Andersen.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317183230/http:/www.joefino.com/Logo_html/L35_Arthur%20Andersen.html "http://www.joefino.com/Logo\_html/L35\_Arthur%20Andersen.html")

Seems to me you are correct that it was a custom job by Fletcher.

Thanks for pointing me towards that!
